questions.text: A 36-year-old woman who regularly wears contact lenses came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of severe pain in right eye along with redness and blurring of vision since the past few days. Her eye is shown below. Which of the following given options can be considered for her treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chlorhexidine

 

Option B:

  • The picture given is characteristic of acanthamoeba keratitis (ring infiltrate).
  • Acanthamoeba keratitis is most frequently associated with contact lens wear, especially if tap water is used for rinsing.

 

TREATMENT OPTIONS:

 

Topical Amoebicides such as:

  • Poly-Hexa-Methylene Biguanide (PHMB) 0.02%
  • Chlorhexidine 0.02%
  • Hexamidine
  • Propamidine

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cefazolin is a cephalosporin antibiotic used against a range of bacterial infections. However, it is not effective against Acanthamoeba and is not used in the treatment of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

Option C. Tobramycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic. While it is effective against various bacterial infections and is commonly used in treating bacterial keratitis, it is not effective against Acanthamoeba.

 

Option D. Voriconazole is an antifungal medication. While it has a broad spectrum of activity, its use in Acanthamoeba keratitis is more limited. It may be considered in certain cases, particularly for fungal co-infections, but it's not a first-line treatment for Acanthamoeba.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of Acanthamoeba keratitis, chlorhexidine is considered effective and is commonly used, as opposed to antibiotics like cefazolin and tobramycin or antifungals like voriconazole, which are not primarily effective against this protozoan infection.

 

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 232

questions.text: A 35-year-old farmer came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of a pain, redness, increased sensitivity to light and blurring of vision in left eye. He gave history of ocular trauma with a twig, 1 day back. After examination, the ophthalmologist suspects fungal keratitis and takes corneal scrapings to confirm her diagnosis. The following organism is observed under the microscope for which immediate treatment is to be initiated to prevent further corneal damage. What is the drug of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Natamycin

 

Option A:

  • The given picture shows filamentous fungi.
  • Fusarium and Aspergillus are the filamentous fungi implicated in fungal keratitis.
  • The drug of choice is Natamycin 5%.
  • Other treatment options include amphotericin B 0.15%, miconazole 1% and voriconazole 1%.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Amphotericin B is more commonly used for yeast-like fungal infections (e.g., Candida) rather than filamentous fungal infections. It can be used in certain cases of severe or resistant fungal keratitis, but it is not the first choice.

 

Option C. Fluconazole is effective against yeasts but has limited activity against filamentous fungi. It is not typically the first-line treatment for filamentous fungal corneal ulcers.

 

Option D. Voriconazole is a broad-spectrum antifungal that can be effective against a wide range of fungi, including filamentous fungi. It is sometimes used in cases where natamycin is ineffective or the fungus is known to be resistant to natamycin. However, natamycin remains the first-line treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of filamentous fungal corneal ulcers, natamycin is the treatment of choice due to its effectiveness against common filamentous fungi that cause these infections.

 

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 218

questions.text: A 29-year-old female came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of a pain in the eye and blurring of vision. She was diagnosed with a corneal ulcer and was sent for corneal scraping. Which of the following topical anaesthetic agents is preferred for the planned procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proparacaine

 

Option C: Topical proparacaine does not inhibit growth of staphylococcus, candida or pseudomonas. Hence preferred compared to other drugs before scraping a corneal ulcer for culture study.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lignocaine is a commonly used local anesthetic in various medical procedures, including ophthalmology. However, it is not the first choice for corneal scraping due to its stinging sensation and relatively longer duration of action, which might not be ideal in this scenario.

 

Option B. Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic. Its longer duration and stronger anesthetic effect make it less ideal for short procedures like corneal scraping, where a quick onset and short duration of action are preferred.

 

Option D. Prilocaine is another local anesthetic, but it is not commonly used in ophthalmology for procedures like corneal scraping. It's more often used in dentistry and for nerve block anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the procedure of corneal scraping in the treatment of corneal ulcers, proparacaine is the preferred topical anesthetic agent due to its rapid onset of action and short duration, which are suitable for this brief and delicate procedure.

 

 

Ref: AAO SECTION: 2 – 2020 EDITION PAGE 412

questions.text: A 40-year-old female who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis presents with pain, redness and watering in right eye. On evaluation she had a dark red swelling in the temporal aspect. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nodular Scleritis

 

Option B:

 

  • Nodular scleritis – less circumscribed nodule noted
  • The swelling is at first dark red or bluish and later becomes purple and semi-transparent like porcelain. Deeper blue-red colour than episcleritis and are immobile also.
  • It may extend entirely around the cornea, forming a very serious condition known as annular scleritis.
  • Most common association of Scleritis is Rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nodular episcleritis: Non-Tender red vascular mobile nodule is seen within interpalpebral fissure.

 

 

Option C. Necrotising scleritis: Serious and aggressive form of Scleritis. Gradual onset of pain that becomes severe and persistent and radiates to the temple, brow or jaw. It would present as thinning and uveal show would be present, unlike nodular scleritis, which presents as a reddish nodule. 

 

 

Option D. Diffuse scleritis: Ocular redness progresses to a pain that may radiate to face and temple. Can involve more than one quadrant of sclera.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nodular scleritis is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 226

questions.text: A 49-year-old female came to the ophthalmologist with redness in her eyes since a few days and a new-onset pain which radiates to face and temple. On examination, bluish-red congestion is seen in the conjunctiva, involving 2 quadrants of the sclera. A diagnosis of Scleritis is made. What is the most serious corneal complication that can occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keratolysis

 

Option C:

 

COMPLICATIONS OF SCLERITIS:

 

  • Sclerosing keratitis
  • Keratolysis (most serious)
  • Staphyloma
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Uveitis
  • Complicated cataract

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sclerosing keratitis refers to corneal inflammation and scarring. While it can be a complication of scleritis, it is not the most serious corneal complication associated with scleritis. It can cause vision impairment but is generally less severe than keratolysis.

 

 

Option B. Corneal opacity is a clouding or loss of transparency in the cornea, which can occur as a result of various eye conditions, including inflammation. While scleritis can lead to corneal opacity, it is not the most serious corneal complication.

 

Option D. Corneal vascularization is the growth of blood vessels into the corneal stroma, often in response to injury or inflammation. While it can occur in scleritis, it is not the most severe corneal complication associated with the condition.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most serious corneal complication of scleritis is Keratolysis.

 

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 227

questions.text: Which form of anterior scleritis presents like this?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrotizing Scleritis with Inflammation

choices.text: Effective mode of treatment is administration of systemic steroids
Sub conjunctival injections of steroids are beneficial

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a three-week history of progressively worsening ocular symptoms. She complains of severe, deep, and boring pain in her right eye, which increases with eye movements. She also notices a gradual onset of decreased vision in the same eye. On examination, there is mild redness and tenderness around the eye, along with proptosis. Fundoscopic examination reveals choroidal folds and swelling of the optic disc. Ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis of posterior scleritis. All the statements given regarding her treatment are true, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Local steroids are not effective.

 

Option C: Ideal treatment for diffuse or nodular scleritis would be

 

  • Oral NSAIDS
  • Oral prednisolone 1 mg/kg as a single dose in the morning for one week which can then be tapered to 20 mg per day over the subsequent 2–3 weeks, or immunosuppressive agents

 

Ideal treatment for necrotizing scleritis would be

 

  • Systemic steroids and immunosuppressives
  • Abundant lubricants are important in scleromalaciaperforans.

 

Ideal treatment for posterior scleritis,

 

  • Systemic NSAIDs, steroids or immunosuppressive therapy.
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone administered as pulse therapy is also effective.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Effective mode of treatment is administration of systemic steroids:

 

  • True. Systemic steroids, such as oral prednisone, are often the mainstay of treatment for posterior scleritis to reduce inflammation and alleviate symptoms.

 

Option B. Subconjunctival injections of steroids are beneficial:

 

  • True. In some cases, subconjunctival injections of steroids may be used as an adjunctive treatment to provide localized anti-inflammatory effects. However, this is usually done in addition to systemic treatment.

 

Option D. Systemic NSAIDs can be given:

 

  • True. Systemic nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can be used as an alternative or adjunctive therapy in the management of posterior scleritis, especially in cases where systemic steroids may not be suitable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic steroids and NSAIDs form the mainstay of treatment of posterior scleritis. Posterior subtenon’s injection of steroids are effective in recalcitrant cases. 

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 228

2. Dutta Majumder, Parthopratim; Agrawal, Rupesh; McCluskey, Peter; Biswas, Jyotirmay. Current Approach for the Diagnosis and Management of Noninfective Scleritis. Asia-Pacific Journal of Ophthalmology 10(2):p 212-223, March-April 2021. | DOI: 10.1097/APO.0000000000000341

questions.text: The differentials for underlying etiology exclude which of the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Degenerative Myopia

 

Option D:

 

  • The given picture is characteristic of INTERCALARY STAPHYLOMA.
  • Location – at the limbus.
  • It is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior most part of the ciliary body.
  • Extent – from limbus to up to 2 mm behind the limbus.

 

CAUSES:

 

  • Perforating injuries of the peripheral cornea
  • Marginal corneal ulcer
  • Anterior scleritis
  • Scleromalaciaperforans
  • Complicated cataract surgery with poor wound apposition
  • Secondary glaucoma

 

Degenerative myopia can lead to Posterior Staphyloma (peripapillary or macular ectasia of the posterior sclera).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Marginal corneal ulcer: Corneal ulcers can lead to tissue damage and thinning in the cornea.

 

Option B. Secondary Glaucoma: Can lead to formation of intercalary staphyloma.

 

Option C. Scleromalaciaperforans: Scleromalaciaperforans is a condition characterized by thinning and weakening of the sclera. It can lead to staphyloma formation, including intercalary staphyloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Degenerative myopia (also known as pathological or malignant myopia): This condition involves excessive axial elongation of the eyeball, which can result in thinning of the posterior sclera.

 

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 229

questions.text: Which of the following topical drugs can be used to differentiate episcleritis from scleritis:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenylephrine

 

Option B: Instillation of 10% phenylephrine drops will constrict the conjunctival and superficial episcleral vasculature but not the deep plexus overlying the nodule – hence in episcleritis blanching occurs but not in scleritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pilocarpine is a miotic agent that constricts the pupil and is primarily used to treat conditions like glaucoma. It is not typically used for differentiating episcleritis from scleritis.

 

Option C. Atropine is a mydriatic agent like phenylephrine but it doesnot have vasoconstrictor properties.

 

Option D. Proparacaine is a topical anesthetic. It is not used for differentiating between episcleritis and scleritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The topical drug used to differentiate episcleritis from scleritis is Phenylephrine

 

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 294
